data.name: Introduction
entries: An ordinary longsword, a gift from your father before entering into the King's service. The bow you carried on your first hunt. The axe that dealt the killing blow to the fearsome bugbear Klarg. To anyone else, these items are unremarkable: they harbour no powerful magic, nor are they central to any great prophecy, or spoken of by storytellers in taverns and around campfires. However, to you, they hold a special significance, and are already part of your story—a story as yet untold.

The first in a series of crafting and toolkit expansions for the fifth edition of Dungeons & Dragons, the {@b Complete Armorer's Handbook} provides a wealth of new options for modifying, upgrading, and maintaining equipment. Moreover, it provides specific and interactive roles for various NPC craftspersons to help breathe life into your games. The worlds of D&D are full of people in need of assistance from an group of courageous adventurers—it can't hurt to introduce a few whose help is needed in turn!

entries.name: Using This Supplement
entries: Written for both players and Dungeon Masters, this supplement provides everything you need to introduce customizable arms and armor into your game. The rules for upgrading equipment presented herein build on the core rules found in {@book chapter 5|phb|5} of the {@b Player's Handbook}. In addition, where reference is made to an appropriate artisan or using an appropriate set of artisan's tools, the "Tool Proficiencies" section in {@book chapter 2|XGE|2|tool proficiencies} of {@b Xanathar's Guide to Everything} should function as your guide.

Chapter 1 covers the primary ruleset for the nonmagical improvement of arms and armor, as well as introducing new types of ammunition for ranged weapons. It also includes optional rules for equipment wear and repair and presents a variety of special materials iconic to the Dungeons & Dragons multiverse that are easily integrated into the base system at your option.

Chapter 2 expands on the runic upgrade presented in the first chapter, acting as the bridge to imbuing mundane equipment with magical effects. Runestones, crafted from gemstones, can be affixed to runic equipment and act as a conduit for the powerful magics contained within, but channeling such magics requiresd attunement by the wielder. This chapter also introduces a complete ruleset enabling characters to create their own runestones using a brand new set of artisan's tools.

entries.name: What the Supplement Provides
entries: This supplement provides a complete framework for putting your heroes in charge of their equipment selection and progression, offering compelling narrative opportunities, and introducing a much-needed structured gold-sink into fifth edition without reverting to magic item shops or adversely affecting game balance. In summary, this supplement is a complete plug and play framework that brings the following benefits to your games:

items: Increased {@b player agency} and foresight over equipment progression—make equipment progression as fun as leveling up!
{@b Narrative investment} in equipment by offering an alternative to replacement as an upgrade path.
A fun and interactive {@b money sink} with tangible benefits and structured progression.
Reduces decision-making overhead on the Dungeon Master.

entries.name: Impact on Game Balance
entries: The material contained herein has been developed and tested over a period of two years for balance, consistency, and adherence to the design expectations of official source material (the runesmithing section is relatively new, but has been a roaring success since its inception!) While the majority of options are easily assessed without great need to stop and consider, unpacking the weapon upgrade options is a more demanding task. As such, an analysis of these upgrades is presented in {@book appendix A|TCAH|3}. In summary, scaling through the weapon upgrade options closely approximates the suggested values for magic items in the {@b {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}} as follows:

entries.caption: Weapon Upgrade Comparison
footnotes: * Cost varies depending on the requirement for the ability to overcoem resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

entries.name: Your Game, Your Rules
entries: There are a lot of options presented in this supplement, each capable of being introduced to your game in any combination or standalone. Using all options—or "all systems go"—is how I run games at my table. However, there is no one-size-fits-all. If you don't like an option, drop it! If something isn't quite right for your game, change it! I encourage you to approach this supplement as a toolbox, from which you can take whatever works for you.

data.name: Arms & Armor
entries: Make improvements, not excuses! So goes the saying of the dwarves of Mithral Hall. Will you hone your blade to a razor's edge, or increase the poundage of your bow with an oiled string? Perhaps your hauberk would benefit from a lining of yeti fur for an upcoming journey into the mountains, or how about integrating a clever climbing harness into your leather armor for some late-night "window shopping"? Rumor also has it there's a new breed of artisan able imbue your equipment with magic.

This chapter details the options available to a character seeking to improve their equipment by having it upgraded by a skilled artisan. Also presented are optional rules for new types of special ammunition, rare and special material, and equipment wear and repair.

entries.name: Upgrading Equipment
entries: When you create your character, you receive equipment based on a combination of your class and background. You decide how you character came by this starting equipment. A sword might be a family heirloom, passed from father to eldest child for generations—but what happens when you find something better in just a few short sessions?

Unfortunately the core rules don't offer any options for the scaling of items alongside the player character—and so that sword is inevitably discarded, cast away and forgotten. The problem is twofold: First, it precludes the integration of your equipment into your story—either as part of a backstory, or an item becoming integral part of a character through play (or indeed, both). Second, responsibility for equipment progression is yet another responsilibity on the shoulders of the Dungeon Master.

This supplement aims to address these issues by providing a player-driven system that seamlessly overlays the core rules without any jagged edges or need for complicated errata. The only requirement for the Dungeon Master is to create new and interesting NPCs that your characters will come to know and love.
Let's get started.

entries.name: The Basics
entries: The process of upgrading a piece of equipment always has a number of basic requirements regardless of its type. The following general rules apply when upgrading equipment using this supplement:

items: Upgrades take the form of {@b tags}. Tags add new properties to equipment.
Each tag is unique and can only be applied to a piece of equipment once.
Upgrading a piece of equipment with a new tag can only be performed by a dedicated NPC craftsperson of the appropriate discipline in a workshop environment.
Upgrading a piece of equipment with a new tag is a skilled endeavour, taking anywhere from an hour to more than a week depending on the task.
On your adventures, you may come across equipment already possessing tags; either for sale, offered as rewards, or available through other means.

entries.name: Upgrading and Magic Items
entries: Due to their extraordinary artisanship and magical reinforcement, magic items can't be modified using normal artisanal methods. As such, the upgrades presented in this chapter can't be applied to magic items.

Furthermore, none of the upgrades presented in this supplement confer "magic item" status to a piece of equipment, though certain upgrades may result in a piece of equipment being considered under certain circumstances.

entries.name: Armor and Shields
entries: This section is intended to compliment and expand on the "Armor and Shields" section in {@book chapter 5|PHB|5} of the {@i Player's Handbook}.

entries.name: Armor Revisions
entries: The {@table Revised Armor|TCAH|Revised Armor table} is intended to replace the Armor table found in the {@b {@i Player's Handbook}}. Previous names are referenced in brackets for the purposes of class equipment selection.

entries.caption: Revised Armor
footnotes: * All medium and heavy armors require a {@item gambeson|TCAH} underlay. If you already possess a {@item gambeson|TCAH} you can subtract 15 gp from the cost when purchasing a suit of medium or heavy armor.

† Heavy armor can be upgraded to the next tier up for the difference in cost. For example, a blacksmith can upgrade a {@item cuirass|TCAH} to a suit of {@item half plate armor|TCAH|half plate} for a cost of 360 gp.

entries.name: Armor Descriptions
entries: The following new types of armor have been added to the Revised Armor table:

entries.name: Brigandine
entries: Brigandine is a sturdy coat of layered linen or leather lined with small steel plates riveted to the fabric.

entries.name: Cuirass
entries: A type of armor formed of a single or multiple pieces of metal that cover the torso. A cuirass generally refers to both a chest plate and back piece together.

entries.name: Gambeson
entries: A gambeson is a padded defensive jacket, either worn separately or as an underlay for heavier types of armor. It can also double as a winter coat.

entries.name: Hauberk
entries: A hauberk is a shirt of mail that reaches at least ot mid-thigh and includes sleeves.

entries.name: Lamellar
entries: This is a type of body armor made from small rectangular paltes (scales or lamellae) of iron, leather, or bronze laced into horizontal rows.

entries.name: Armor Properties
entries: The "Properties" column in the Revised Armor table replaces the previous "Stealth" column, with the following definitions:

entries.name: Disadvantage (Stealth)
entries: You have disadvantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) made while wearing this armor.

entries.name: Special (Tower Shield)
entries: You can't make opportunity attacks while holding this shield.

entries.name: Upgrading Armor
entries: There are a number of options available to a character to upgrade their armor, from high-cost armor proofing, to useful additions like insulation suitable for cold weather environments. A complete list of these options, as well as cost and any additional requirements, are shown in the {@table Armor Upgrades|TCAH|Armor Upgrades table} on the following page. In addition to the basic rules for upgrading, the following rules apply when upgrading a suit of armor or a shield with a new tag:

items: Any prerequisite conditions must be satisfied to apply a new tag, as shown in the Armor Upgrades table.
Typically, it takes an artisan a full day of work (minimum 8 hours) to upgrade a suit of armor or a shield with a new tag.

items.name: Armor Proofing
entries: The proofing process normally requires a full workweek (5 days) and can only be undertaken by a master artisan. Once added, armor proofing tags can't be removed from a suit of armor.

entries.name: Armor Proofing
entries: The primary method of upgrading armor, proofing is the process of testing and improving a suit of armor's ability to withstand blows of various types below a certain threshold, being certified as proof against swords, arrows, and warhammers. While all types of armor can be proofed against slashing damage, only medium and heavy armors can be proofed against piercing damage, and only heavy armor can be proofed against bludgeoning attacks.

entries.name: Other Upgrades
entries: In addition to proofing, various other upgrades are available to armors meeting the prerequisites for each, as shown in the Armor Upgrades table. Certain upgrades are incompatible, such as the {@b {@i breathable}} and {@b {@i insulated}} tags, while others have specific requirements (for example, the {@b {@i runic}} tag can only be applied by a runesmith.) Certain types of armor upgrade tags may be removable or temporary. For example, you may be able to remove the {@b {@i muffled}} tag by extracting the padding sewn into the joints. When in doubt, consult with your DM.

entries.name: Variant: Armor Proofing
entries: Your DM might allow you to replace the properties of armor proofing with a bonus to Armor Class. In this case, each tier of proofing provides a cumulative +1 bonus to AC, and the cost of each is tripled.

entries.caption: Armor Upgrades
rows: While wearing this armor, if you would take 6 or less nonmagical slashing damage before resistance is applied, you take none of that damage instead.
Medium or heavy armor with {@i 1st tier armor proofing} tag
While wearing this armor, if you would take 7 or less nonmagical slashing or piercing damage before resistance is applied, you take none of that damage instead.
Heavy armor with the {@i 2nd tier armor proofing} tag
While wearing this armor, if you would take 8 or less nonmagical slashing, piercing, or bludgeoning damage before resistance is applied, you take none of that damage instead.
Light or medium armor. Incompatible with the {@i insulated} tag.
While wearing this armor, you have advantage on saving throws you make against exhaustion effects due to extreme heat, as described in {@book chapter 5|DMG|5} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

This armor has been polished to a mirror finish. While wearing it, you may have advantage on Charisma-based skill checks when interacting with certain humanoids, as determined by the DM. This tag is automatically removed after 24 hours of wear or at the end of a combat.

This armor has been modified with a climbing harness around the midriff, comprising leather straps and quickdraws. While wearing it, you make Strength (Athletics) checks to scale vertical surfaces with advantage when using a rope or similar aid.
Medium or heavy armor and shields
This armor or shield is adorned with a holy symbol and can be used as a spellcasting focus for cleric and paladin spells.
This armor counts as cold weather gear in conditions of extreme cold, as described in {@book chapter 5|DMG|5} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

This armor is made with hinged joints that can be locked by a quick motion from the wearer. While wearing it, you make Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks to oppose attempts to shove you with advantage.
This armor no longer confers disadvantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.
You can doff this armor as an action.
This armor has been reinforced at the joints and other weak points. While wearing it, critical damage you take from nonmagical attacks is reduced by 3.
{@i Armor proofing} tag (any tier) or a shield. Can only be applied by a runesmith*.
This armor or shield can be imbued with rune magic.*
This armor has been modified with spikes, barbs, or other similar feature, and deals {@dice 1d4} piercing damage to creatures attacking with unarmed strikes or natural weapons that aren't magical.
footnotes: See {@book chapter 2|TCAH|2}, "Rune Magic".

entries.name: Weapons
entries: This section is intended to compliment and expand on the "{@book Weapons|PHB|5|Weapons}" section in {@book chapter 5|PHB|5} of the {@b {@i Player's Handbook}}.

entries.name: Weapon Revisions
entries: The following new properties have been added to certain weapons. The {@table Revised Weapons|TCAH|Revised Weapons table} reflects these changes in {@b bold} for easy reference:

entries.name: Bandolier (daggers and darts)
entries: When making a ranged attack with a weapon that has the bandolier property, you can immediately draw another weapon of the same type as part of the attack.

entries.name: Concealed (blowguns, daggers, darts, hand crossbows, and slings)
entries: You have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) checks you make to keep this weapon hidden.

entries.name: Limited (hand crossbows)
entries: Possession of this weapon is restricted in some soceities, often requiring a special dispensation, rank, or permit.

entries.name: Siege (greatclubs and mauls)
entries: This weapon deals double damage to objects and structures.
In addition, the {@b heavy} property has been added to greatclubs.

entries.name: Upgrading Weapons
entries: Upgrading weapons follows a branching path system, with available options split into multiple tiers. At first, a weapon can only be upgraded with a limited selection of 1st tier tags depending on its type, each of which "unlocks" one or more options from the next tier. The following additional rules apply when upgrading a weapon with a new tag:

items: All prerequisite conditions must be satisfied to apply a new tag, as shown in the {@table Weapon Upgrades|TCAH|Weapon Upgrades table}.
2nd tier upgrades can only be applied by a trained craftsman, with 3rd tier upgrades requiring the skills of a master artisan.
Typically, it takes an artisan a full day of work (minimum 8 hours) to upgrade a weapon with a new tag.
Once added, a tag can't be removed from a weapon.

entries.name: Weapon Upgrade Cost Structure
entries: Upgrading a weapon has a base cost associated with each tier, with subsequent upgrades of that tier costing twice the previous amount for that tier. For example, Erik decides to pay a visit to a local blacksmith in order to have a customized pommel attached to his dagger—adding the {@b {@i balanced}} tag—for the tier 1 base cost of 100 gp. Later, he returns to have the blade honed—adding the {@b {@i sharpened}} tag—this time costing 200 gp, with the next 1st tier upgrade costing 400 gp, and so on.

Upgrades are grouped by tier for the purposes of this cost scaling: continuing with the above example, if Erik then wishes to have the blade of his dagger partially serrated in order to improve its effectiveness when slicing and cutting—adding the {@b {@i saw-toothed}} tag—it would cost 1,000 gp (the 2nd tier base cost) provided that the dagger doesn't already possess any other 2nd tier tags.

entries.caption: Weapon Upgrades

row: You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls made with this weapon.
Melee weapons that deal piercing or slashing damage only
Attacks with this weapon score a critical hit on a roll one lower than normal.*
Attacks with this weapon score a critical hit on a roll one lower than normal.*
Melee weapons that deal bludgeoning damage only
Attacks with this weapon score a critical hit on a roll one lower than normal.*
Can only be applied by a runesmith†
This weapon can be imbued with rune magic.
Attacks with this weapon count as silvered for the purposes overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.
You gain a +1 bonus to damage rolls made with this weapon.
You gain a +1 bonus to damage rolls made with this weapon.

When you attack with this weapon and roll the maximum result for the weapon's damage dice, you can roll these dice again and add the new roll to the damage of the attack. If you roll the maximum amount again, you can repeat this process until you don't.
Any 1st tier tag. Can only be applied by an arcane spellcaster. Quarterstaffs only.
You gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls while using this weapon as a spellcasting focus.
{@i Spiked} tag. Can only be applied to maces and mauls
When you hit a creature wearing medium or heavy armor with this weapon you sunder its armor, inflicting a cumulative -1 penalty to its Armor Class until the armor is repaired.
{@i Silvered} tag. Can only be applied by an arcane spellcaster

Attacks with this weapon count as magical for the purposes of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage, and features such as {@creature black pudding}'s {@i corrosive form}.
{@i Sharpened} tag. Can only be applied to daggers.
Attacks with this weapon deal an extra {@dice 1d4} slashing damage. No effect against constructs or undead.
{@i Balanced, keen,} or {@i oiled string} tag. Can only be applied to weapons with one damage die.
The damage die of this weapon is increased by one size (for example, {@dice 1d6} becomes {@dice 1d8}, and {@dice 1d10} becomes {@dice 1d12}) to a maximum of {@dice 1d12}.
{@i Enchanted} tag. Can only be applied by an arcane spellcaster
You gain a +1 bonus to your spell save DC while using this weapon as a spellcasting focus.
You gain an additional +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

footnotes: * For example, if you normally score a critical hit on a roll of 20 you instead score one on a roll of 19 or 20
† See {@book chapter 2|TCAH|2}, "Rune Magic".

entries.name: Additional Options
entries: This section presents some additional options to further enhance the armory system in your campaign.

entries.name: Special Ammunition
entries: The following new types of ammunition may be available for ranged weapons; either found as loot, available to purchase, or as an option to craft during downtime:

entries.name: Berserk Dart
entries: The poison in this dart can induce temporary psychosis in a creature subjected to it. When you hit a creature with an attack using this ammunition, it must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or go berserk. While berserk, it must use its action each round to attack the creature nearest to it. At the end of each of its turns, the target can make another Constitution saving throw, ending the effect on a success. A creature that has succeeded on the save has advantage on subsequent saves made to resist the effects of this poison for 24 hours. No effect against undead and creatures immune to being {@condition charmed}. Once a berserk dart hits a creature, it loses this property and becomes a normal dart.

entries.name: Blunt
entries: A flat-nosed arrowhead typically used for target practice and hunting small game animals such as rabbits, squirrels, and grouse. Successful attacks using this ammunition deal {@dice 1d4} nonlethal bludgeoning damage instead of the weapon's normal damage.

entries.name: Bodkin
entries: The tip of a bodkin arrow is most commonly a sharpened spike with a square profile, designed to penetrate plate and mail armor. You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls against targets wearing armor when using this ammunition.

entries.name: Broadhead
entries: With a tip shaped like a spear point, broadheads are designed for maximum penetration of soft flesh and thick hide—commonly used by hunters for bringing down large game. When you hit a creature that isn't wearing armor with an attack using this ammunition it takes an extra {@dice 1d6} piercing damage.

entries.name: Firecracker
entries: This ammunition is tipped with a volatile alchemical compound. On striking a hard surface, it explodes creating a flash of light and loud crack audible out to 100 feet.

entries.name: Shadow
entries: Enchanted with magic from the Shadowfell, this ammunition is able to strike creatures in the Ethereal Plane, and counts as magical for the purposes of overcoming resistance to immunity and nonmagical attacks and damage.

entries.name: Sleep Dart
entries: This dart contains a dose of a powerful soporific, designed to temporarily incapacitate a target. When you hit a creature with an attack using this ammunition, instead of dealing damage roll {@dice 5d8}; if the target has fewer hit points than the total rolled it falls {@condition unconscious} until one hour has passed, it takes damage, or someone uses and action to shake or slap the target awake. No effect against undead and creatures immune to being {@condition charmed}. Once a sleep dart hits a creature, it loses this property and becomes a normal dart.

entries.caption: Special Ammunition
footnotes: The cost of silvered arrows as presented in the Player's Handbook has been reduced by 75%

entries.name: Crafting Special Ammunition
entries: In addition to the appropriate tools for the item to be crafted, a character needs raw materials worth half of the produced item's selling cost. A character proficient with the tools needed to craft the item and with access to the appropriate equipment can craft 10 gp's worth of special ammunition for every 8 hours spent.

entries.name: Special Materials
entries: On your adventures you may encounter or have the opportunity to create equipment constructed using the following special materials:

entries.name: Adamantine
entries: An ultra-hard alloy of adamant and electrum. Adamantine is black with a green tinge that sharpens to purple-white under light from most magical sources. Armor made of adamantine reduces incoming bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage by 3 if it's heavy armor, or 2 if it's medium armor. Shields made from adamantine have a +1 bonus to AC. Equipment made from adamantine can't be destroyed, damaged or suffer from wear.

entries.name: Cold Iron
entries: A rare pure-formed iron, mined deep underground and forged at lower temperatures to preserve its delicate properties. Weapons made of cold iron deal an additional weapon damage die against fey creatures.

entries.name: Darkwood (Zalantar)
entries: This rare magical wood has similar properties to beech, oak and yew for bow-making while being extremely light and durable. {@item longbow|phb|Longbows} and {@item heavy crossbow|phb|heavy crossbows} made of darkwood don't have the heavy property.

entries.name: Deep Crystal
entries: Deep crystal is a mineral of above-average quality found at the heart of large veins or deposits, and is renowned for its strength and magically resonant nature. Weapons made of deep crystal can be used as a spellcasting focus.

entries.name: Dragonhide
entries: A rare type of leather armor made from the supple underbelly hide of a dragon. While wearing dragonhide armor you have resistance to the damage type associated with the dragon from which it is made (for example, blue dragonhide armor confers resistance to lightning damage).

entries.name: Ironwood
entries: Ironwood is a magical substance created from normal wood by druids. While remaining natural wood in almost every way, ironwood is as strong, heavy, and resistant to fire as steel. Spells and effects that affect metal do not affect ironwood, whereas spells that affect wood do—although ironwood will not burn.

entries.name: Mithral
entries: Known to the dwarves as truemetal, this shining silvery-blue metal is lighter than steel yet just as durable. Equipment made of mithral weighs only half as much as the same item made of normal metals, and has no Strength requirement. Additionally, armor made of mithral can be worn under normal clothes, and doesn't impose disadvantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks when it otherwise would. Small creatures do not have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons made of mithral.

entries.name: Shadowsilk
entries: Highly prized by assassins and cutpurses, shadowsilk is cloth made from magically woven shadowstuff. While wearing normal clothing or a gambeson made of shadowsilk and no other armor, you have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks when attempting to hide in dim light or darkness.

entries.name: Rules for Special Materials
entries: The following general rules apply to arms and armor constructed using special materials:

items: Armor and shields constructed using adamantine or dragonhide have a base cost equal to twenty times that of the same item made exclusively of normal materials. Armor and shields constructed using other special materials have a base cost equal to ten times as much.

Weapons made of special materials vary in price, typically costing upwards of 2,000 gp. In addition, weapons made of special materials automatically possess the silvered and magical tags, which count when determining the cost of any subsequent upgrades.

entries.name: Note on Mithral and Adamantine
entries: The options for adamantine and mithral presented herein are intended to replace the adamantine and mithral armors found in {@book chapter 5|DMG|5} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}. The properties of adamantine have been adjusted to more closely reflect its more iconic status of previous editions.

entries.name: Wear and Repair
entries: You can use the following rules for equipemnt wear and repair to add an extra dimension to your campaign:

entries.name: Equipment Properties
entries: The following tags can't be added as upgrades, but may be found preexisting on looted or for-sale items, ar applied automatically when certain conditions are met.

entries.name: Worn or Sundered
entries: This piece of equipment has been damaged in combat or has deteriorated with age and use. A worn or sundered weapons confers a -1 penalty to attack and damage rolls made with it, and the AC of worn or sundered armor is reduced by 1.

entries.name: Damaged
entries: This piece of equipment has sustained significant damage and will break when you roll a 1 on the {@dice d20} for an attack made with it (weapons) or you take damage from a critical hit while wearing it (armor and shields).

entries.name: Broken
entries: A broken weapon or shield cannot be wielded, and the AC of broken armor is reduced by 5, to a minimum of 10.

entries.name: Variant: Damaging Equipment
entries: If your group enjoys more tactical combat, consider allowing worn or sundered armor to become damaged on sustaining damage form a critical hit, and a worn or sundered weapon to become damaged when you roll a 1 on the {@dice d20} for an attack roll made with it.

entries.name: Repairing Equipment
entries: A character proficient with and in possession of an appropriate set of artisan's tools can attempt to repair worn, damaged, or broken equipment as follows:

items: Equipment that is {@b worn} or {@b sundered} can be repaired for a fixed cost of 10 gp, or by spending 1 hour and succeeding on a DC 15 repair check with an appropriate set of tools.

Equipment that is {@b damaged} can be repaired for a cost equal to 10 gp or 10% of the base cost of the item (whichever is higher), or by spending 4 hours and succeeding on a DC 20 repair check with an apporpriate set of tools.

Equipment that is {@b broken} can be repaired for a cost equal to 50% of the base cost of the equipment. The task of repairing broken equipment can only be undertaken in a workshop environment, and takes anywhere from a full day to more than a week depending on the type and quality of the equipment and the extent of the work required. Proofed armor that is broken can only be repaired by a master artisan.

data.name: Rune Magic
entries: The ancient practice of rune magic originated with giants durign the age when Ostoria ruled an area of Faerûn from the Vilhon reach to the Cold Lands. Since that time, the dwarves have studied the techniques of the skiltgravr ("rune cutters"), adapting the rune magic of the giants and making it their own.

Rune magic allows a character to access the magical potential of sigils created by the first runesmiths and their contemporaries. This chapter describes runestones—engraved gemstones used to channel rune magic—and the ways in which they might be encountered in your world, as well as rules for creating them.

entries.name: Runestones
entries: Runestones are gemstones used as foci for the magic contained within the sigils engraved onto them by runesmiths. a prized export of dwarven society, they are sold to wealthy adventurers and mercenaries as a means of empowering their arms and armor. In a world where magic items are increasingly rare, the dwarves work with typical industry to meet an ever-expanding demand.

entries.name: Using Runestones
entries: The following rules apply to the use of runestones:

items: In order to use a runestone, it must first be affixed to a piece of equipment with the {@b {@i runic}} tag. Only equipment with the {@b {@i runic}} tag can channel the magical properties of runestones.
A creature must be atttuned to the item to gain the benefits of an affixed rune.
A runestone can be removed from a piece of equipemnt, but it is destroyed in the process.
For magical effects created by runestones, your spell attack modifier and spell save DC use the ability modifier of the weapon used for the attack.

entries.name: Awarding Runestones
entries: Awarding runestones should follow the general guidelines for awarding magic items found in the {@b {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}} and {@b {@i Xanathar's Guide to Everything}} when planning treasure rewards. Here are a few ways to integrate runestones into your campaign:

items: Runestones can be found in treasure hoards, shops, or offered as quest rewards either alongside or in lieu of magic items of an equivalent rarity.
They might only be available through a recognized guild—such as the Runesmith's Guild—or other trading house, and supply may be restricted to qualifying persons or locations.

entries.name: Identifying Runestones
entries: Runestones are identified in a manner similar to identifying magic items. Simply handling a runestone causes a strong sense of its identity to echo in a character's mind. For example, touching a runestone engraved with the {@b {@i tempest}} rune might cause the hair on your neck to stand on end as visions of battle and thunderstorms flash through your mind. As the runes are based on modern Dethek, those able to read Dwarvish can comprehend their general meaning, which may provide clues about the runestone's nature and properties.

The {@spell identify} spell immediately reveals a runestone's properties. You can also learn its properties over the course of a short rest while maintaining physical contact with it, or by succeeding on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check using a set of runesmith's tools.

entries.name: Runesmithing
entries: Characters wishing to craft their own runestones can do so following the rules in this section.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: A runesmith uses a special set of tools in order to engrave gemstones with magical sigils. In addition to the information below, use of these tools follows the general guidelines for the artisan's tools found in {@book chapter 2|XGE|2}, "Tool Proficiencies" of {@b {@i Xanathar's Guide to Everything}}.

entries.name: Runesmith's Tools
entries: Proficiency with runesmith's tools allows you to etch magical runes into precious stones, as well as identify aspects of their lore when encountered in the world. A set of runesmith's tools costs 25 gp and weighs 5 lb.

entries.name: Components
entries: Runesmith's tools include a hammer, a set of chisels and needle files, a fine-haired brush, a bouch of powdered mithral, and a special alchemical lacquer.

entries.name: Arcana and History
entries: Your expertise lends you additional insights about lore associated with rounes and other sigils carved into stone or other surface.

entries.name: Investigation
entries: You can spot clues and make deductions that others might overlook when inspecting items or surfaces carved with runes and other sigils.

entries.caption: Runesmith's Tools
rows: Identify the properties of a runestone
Determine the creator of a runestone

entries.name: Moonlighting
entries: Trading in runestones outside of authorized channels is strictly forbidden. Every runesmith leaves an aura—like a magical fingerprint—on runestones they create, so be careful!

entries.name: Crafting Requirements
entries: In order to engage in runesmithing a character must be proficient with and have access to a set of {@item runesmith's tools|TCAH}, with proficiency representing the base level of competency needed to wield the tools effectively. In addition to a set of {@item runesmith's tools|TCAH}, a gemstone is required onto which the runes are engraved to fashion a runestone. The minimum required quality of the gemstone (as denoted by its value) depends on the strength of the runestone being created (as denoted by its rarity), as shown in the Runesmithing table:

entries.name: Crafting Process
entries: Once all requirements are met, the process of creating a runestone is performed over a two hour period, which can be split into shorter sessions such as during a short rest. At the end of the period, make a craft check using your {@item runesmith's tools|TCAH}. When you make this check, you don't benefit from any bonuses (such as Bardic Inspiration) except your own ability score and proficiency bonus, unless you benefitted from the bonus for the duration of the period.

On a success, the gemstone is engraved successfully and becomes a runestone, otherwise the gemstone is destroyed. The DC depends on the rarity of the runestone, as shown in the {@table Runesmithing|TCAH} table. {@book Appendix C|TCAH|5} presents a reference set of tables to help a player quickly ascertain the chances of success of a given crafting attempt.

entries.name: Runesmith's Guild
entries: The Runesmith's Guild is the official guild for the study and practice of runesmithing and rune magic. Founded in Gauntlgrym during the Age of the Proud Peoples, today the guild is headquartered in the city of Neverwinter with a presence in many major settlements throughout the Realms. This section presents an optional framework for incorporating the guild into your campaign.

entries.name: Joining the Guild
entries: Any character proficient with a set of {@b {@item runesmith's tools|TCAH}} can become an apprentice of the Runesmith's Guild by registering with a guild union representative and paying a registration fee of 10 gp.

entries.name: Increasing Your Standing
entries: You must pass exams in order to increase your standing within the guild. For each exam, candidates are tasked with crafting the test item specified in the Guild Exams table. Exams are scheduled at the end of every month.

To be eligibile to sit an exam, a character must have paid for that term's tuition. Tuition time and cost varies depending on the level of instruction, as shown in the Guild Tuition table. Tuition is undertaken for the next level of guild advancement. For example, a craftsman will receive tuition at the artisan level in order to prepare for advancement to that rank.

Candidates sitting an exam must supply their own gemstone, or they can purchase one from guild stocks. Exams are invigilated by a master or grandmaster and last for two hours, during which time all forms of magic and magical effects are suppressed as if by an {@spell antimagic field} spell. At the end of the period, make a craft check using your runesmith's tools, following the normal rules for crafting a runestone. You make this check with advantage if you have attended a full tuition term (taken as a downtime activity). On a success, you pass the exam and your new rank is recognized. Runestones created during exams are withheld by the guild to pay taxes levied by the local lord or governor, often by supplying the nearest garrison.

entries.name: Rank Benefits
entries: The following benefits are immediately conferred to members on attaining a new rank. All rank benefits are cumulative.

entries.name: Journeyman
entries: You have demonstrated the basic care and comepetencies expected of a runesmith. As a result of your studies, you gain a +1 bonus to checks you make to craft runestones of common rarity.

entries.name: Craftsman
entries: You are recognized as a full member of the guild. You gain a +1 bonus to checks you make to craft runestones of uncommon rarity. Full members are able to perform guild work during downtime (see below).

entries.name: Artisan
entries: You have demonstrated the capabilities of a veteran of the guild. You gain a +1 bonus to checks you make to craft rare runestones. Guild artisans are eligible for the {@feat Runesmithing Adept|TCAH} feat (see next page).

entries.name: Master
entries: Through diligent study, you have achieved the status of a master runesmith. You gain a +1 bonus to checks you make to craft very rare runestones.

entries.name: Grandmaster
entries: You have ascended to the rank of grandmaster. You gain a +1 bonus to checks you make to craft legendary runestones. Grandmasters are invited to attend meetings of the council, and often head local chapters.

entries.name: Guild Downtime Activities
entries: The downtime rules presented in this section are intended to compliment and expand on the "{@variantrule Downtime Revisited|XGE}" section in {@book chapter 2|XGE|2} of {@b {@i Xanathar's Guide to Everything}}.

entries.name: Guild Work
entries: Members of the guild can spend time in the workhalls filling orders placed by clients.

entries.name: Resources
entries: Guild work requires at least one day's labor. Equipment and materials are supplied by the guild.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: Standard renumeration for guild work depends on your guild rank as follows:

entries.caption: Guild Work
rows: Modest lifestyle for the week + 5 gp per day of work
Comfortable lifestyle for the week + 10 gp per day of work
Wealthy lifestyle for the week + 20 gp per day of work
Aristocratic lifestyle for the week + 50 gp per day of work.

entries.name: Complications
entries: Performing guild work rarely results in significant complications. Still, working for the guild is not without risk. Each workweek spent filling orders brings a 10% chance a complication.

entries.caption: Work Complications
rows: A customer cancels an order, reducing your earnings for the week by one category.
You work for a lucrative contract, increasing your earnings for the week b one rank category.
Your tools are damaged or stolen, forcing you to buy new ones.*
An incident occurs in the workhall for which you are blamed (justified or not, as you choose). You are barred from the workhall for the next 6 workweeks.*
You are accused of selling runestones outide of guild channels by a colleague.*
A runestone bearing your magical signature was used to commit a crime.*
footnotes: * Might involve a rival.

entries.name: Additional Options
entries: This section presents some additional options to further enhance the rune magic system in your campaign.

entries.name: Tool Feats
entries: The runesmithing system presented in this chapter assumes that double proficiency can be obtained by characters wishing to become an accomplished artisan. As such, it is advised to allow the following new feat (or similar) in games that allow feats:

entries.name: Runesmithing Adept
entries: {@b {@i Prerequisite: Artisan of the Runesmith's Guild (if using the guild system)
You have excelled in your study of runesmithing and are regarded as a prodigy by your peers, gaining the following benefits:

items: Increase your Dexterity or Intelligence score by 1, to a maximum of 20.
Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with {@item runesmith's tools|TCAH}

Over the course of a short rest, you can attempt to remove a runestone affixed to a piece of equipment without destroying it. At the end of the short rest, make a check with your {@item runesmith's tools|TCAH}, where the DC is equal to the DC to create the runestone. On a success, the runestone is recovered.

entries.name: Artificer Infusions
entries: The following new infusions are available to artificers. The description of each infusion details the type of item that can receive it, and follow the normal rules for artificer infusions found in {@book chapter 1|ERLW|1} of {@b {@i Eberron: Rising from the Last War}}.

entries.name: Runestones A-Z
entries: This section describes the most common runestones in the world of Dungeons & Dragons. Beginning with a brief list of runestones, sorted by type and rarity, followed by their descriptions presented in alpabetical order.
The descriptions of the runes can be found in the {@filter Other Options & Features|optionalfeatures|source=TCAH|feature type=RS:C;RS:UC;RS:R;RS:VR;RS:L} page.

data.name: Weapon Upgrade Analysis
entries: This appendix discusses the mathematical reasoning and other factors concerning the weapon upgrade system.

entries.name: Numerical Balancing
entries: The following table presents the average damage dealt per attack by a 5th level character (+4 ability modifier) for a weapon with each upgrade individually (no other upgrades) using on a Monte Carlo simulation of 50,000 rounds of attacks against a Normal Distribution of CR-appropriate enemies for that level (model assumes a mean AC of 15 with a 1.5 Standard Deviation.) For ease of comparison, a baseline (no upgrades) is presented following the same methodology:

entries.caption: Damage Anaylsis: Individual Upgrades
footnotes: * Average damage reported for the saw-toothed tag assumes 100% applicability (no undead or construct targets).

entries: In addition, the following table presents the average damage of a fully-upgraded weapon against a baseline +3 magic weapon for various categories of weapon grouped by die size and available upgrade mix at 15th level (+5 ability modifier, model assumes a mean AC of 18 with a 2.0 Standard Deviation) following the same methodology:

entries.caption: Damage Analysis: Fully-upgraded Weapon
rows: {@item Handaxe|PHB}, {@item javelin|PHB}, {@item mace|PHB}, {@item quarterstaff|PHB}, {@item scimitar|PHB}, {@item shortsword|PHB}, {@item spear|PHB}, {@item trident|PHB}
{@item Battleaxe|phb}, {@item greatclub|phb}, {@item longsword|phb}, {@item morningstar|phb}, {@item rapier|phb}, {@item war pick|phb}, {@item warhammer|phb}
footnotes: * Additionally, the flanged tag is available to maces and mauls at a final additional cost of 8,000 and 4,000 gp, respectively.

entries.name: Power Creep
entries: A fully-upgraded {@dice 2d6} weapon—the highest average damage—is equal to the baseline to within one decimal place, showing that the upgrade system doesn't exceed magical weapons at the top end. In addition, there is an increasing relative improvement for weapons with lower average damage, which helps to reward and incentivize their use.

entries.name: Great Weapons
entries: A fully-upgraded {@dice 1d12} weapon possesses higher average damage than an equivalent {@dice 2d6} weapon due to stronger synergy with the {@b {@i brutal}} tag. This presents the player with an interesting choice: higher initial damage ({@dice 2d6}) versus higher average final damage ({@dice 1d12}). Furthermore, the 2d6 maul benefits the new siege property (if you are using the new weapon properties) and also has access to the {@b {@i flanged}} upgrade—offering an attractive option at an additional cost.

entries.name: Glaive, Halberd, and Pike
entries: These weapons can match a {@item greataxe|phb} for an additional cost of 4,000 gp. Functionally, this is 4,000 gp for the reach property at the finish line, which is fine.

entries.name: Ranged Weapons
entries: {@item Blowguns|phb} and {@item darts|phb} are significantly below the baseline, but gain exclusive access to powerful new types of special ammunition. Bows and crossbows are also below the baseline, and are likewise accounted for by the availability of special ammunition. In both cases, the lower total cost of upgrading is offset by the additional cost of ammunition.

entries.name: Daggers
entries: {@item Dagger|PHB|Daggers} benefit from an exceptional relative increase over the baseline thanks to exclusive access to the {@b {@i saw-toothed}} tag. This is personal taste, but its always bothered me that the iconic dagger is so mechanically suboptimal for a rogue. This closes the gap to the {@item rapier|phb} subsantially without the need for an errata of official material, and also provides the dagger with some unique flavor.

data.name: Weapon Upgrade Quick Reference
entries: The tables in this appendix are intended as convenient reference for players when determining available upgrades for each weapon type, the process for which is described in chapter 1.

data.name: Runesmithing Probability Tables
entries: The tables in this appendix are intended as convenient reference for players to quickly determine the chances of success of a given crafting attempt. For each additional +1 bonus to the roll the chances of success are increased by 5%.

entries.caption: Runesmithing Success Rate—Double Proficiency
footnotes: * Assumes Dexterity or Intelligence as a primary ability score with a typical rate of progression using the Standard Array.

data.name: FAQ
entries: This appendix seeks to clarify some of the most common queries from users of this supplement. Questions are presented in the natural order they might occur while reading the text.

entries.name: Why base the system on money?
entries: In short, because that's what money is for: a universal medium of exchange for goods and services. It's far more believable than alternative systems like exponential (and often unreasonable) time scaling or arbitrary level-locking. These alternatives are mechanically fine, but they feel very much like artificial restrictions (because they are).

Furthermore, using money allows players to make universal value judgements. Could the fighter potentially upgrade their weapon at a faster-than-anticipated rate? Absolutely—if the group is willing to pay the opportunity cost (i.e. less gold for other things), which has a ripple effect far beyond the boundaries of this system. The more decisions you can hitch to money, the more valuable and interesting money becomes. As stated in the introduction, this is my first such supplement to be released on the Dungeon Masters Guild, but it won't be the last!

entries.name: Am I awarding enough money?
entries: The best answer to this question is if the party has enough to afford some of the (level-appropriate) things they want but not everything then you're on the right track or thereabouts. This supplement is based on the relevant sections of the {@b {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}}, including the expected rate of accrual of wealth using the Treasure Hoard tables therein. This means that—used standalone—this supplement should put you on that right track. If, however, you incorporate additional money sinks (such as those in Strongholds & Followers) then consider increasing money-rewards accordingly, perhaps increasing the amount of coin awarded and decreasing magic item rewards by a commensurate amount (or allowing the group to sell any surplus magic items). Exercise your judgement based on the needs of your campaign.

entries.name: Can I make magic weapons upgradable?
entries: Yes! The system can easily accommodate this. First, you should attempt to "recreate" the weapon as closely as possible using a base weapon and any combination of upgrade tags in order to determine what tags it might already possesses. For example, to recreate the {@item dagger of venom|DMG} from the {@b {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}}:

items: Add the {@b {@i silvered}} and {@b {@i magical}} tags to overcome resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.
Add both the {@b {@i balanced}} and {@b {@i wounding—keen}} tags to gain a +1 bonus to attacks and damage made with this weapon.
Add the {@b {@i runic}} tag and create an appropriate rune with the properties of the poisoning action described in the item text.

entries: The above recreates the {@item dagger of venom|DMG} as if it were made following the rules in chapter 1. The dagger now requires attunement by the wielder (to gain the benefits of the affixed rune) but can now be upgraded!

entries.name: Which dice count for the brutal tag?
entries: The {@b {@i brutal}} tag {@u only} considers the weapon's damage dice, which means base weapon damage dice plus additional rolls of those dice from a critical hit. This doesn't include extra damage from other sources such as Divine Smite, Sneak Attack, the {@b {@i saw-toothed}} tag, and the {@optfeature tempest|TCAH} runestone.

entries.name: Can I add upgrade tags of my own?
entries: Absolutely! For armor there is no issue because (armor proofing notwithstanding) available upgrades are independent of one another. For weapons, the cost-doubling nature of the system ensures that you can keep adding upgrades beyond what's presented while keeping any power creep cost-appropriate (i.e. exponential). For example, you could create a new 1st tier focus tag that enables a weapon to be used as a spellcasting focus for your spells.

Furthermore, you can scale the weapon upgrade system into epic levels by creating a new 4th tier with a base cost of 100,000 gp, and even a 5th tier with a base cost of 1,000,000 gp—though presumably these tiers are beyond the skillset of even a master artisan, and the group will need to entreat a higher power for assistance!

entries.name: Why can't light armor be upgraded as much as heavy armor?
entries: A tangential benefit of the armor upgrade system is giving heavier armors a bit more "oomph" than under the default rules, where Dexterity and light armor are typically regarded as king. If you don't like it, the power is yours.

entries.name: The muffled tag overlaps with the Medium Armor Master feat!
entries: You have a keen eye, Watson! Indeed, while I usually loathe to befoul official material in this way (overlapping or redundant features and such), after much consideration the muffled tag remains to my eye the more natural means of obtaining this particular benefit. As such, in games that use feats consider replacing the first bullet of the {@feat Medium Armor Master|PHB} feat with the following:

items: Increase your Dexterity score by 1, to a maximum of 20.

entries.name: Are there rules for when a piece of equipment becomes worn through use?
entries: During the creation of this ruleset we tried a variety of mechanics to "track" equipment degredation, and ultimately found none worth the time and effort of doing so. Instead, a simple "milestone" approach (whereby the DM reminds players when their gear might starting to show signs of wear) seems to be the best approach.

entries.name: Can I add runestones of my own?
entries: New runestones are always being created or discovered by members of the Runesmith's Guild! Magic items are a popular field of study, meaning an easy way to create your own runestones is to use the properties of your favorite magic items. Who knows, maybe a bounty is offered by the guild for magic items with undiscovered properties or will accept donations of such items for study—offering the donor a runestone imbued with its magical properties once they have been decoded.

variantrule.name: Wear and Repair; Repairing Equipment
entries: A character proficient with and in possession of an appropriate set of artisan's tools can attempt to repair worn, damaged, or broken equipment as follows:

items: Equipment that is {@b worn} or {@b sundered} can be repaired for a fixed cost of 10 gp, or by spending 1 hour and succeeding on a DC 15 repair check with an appropriate set of tools.

Equipment that is {@b damaged} can be repaired for a cost equal to 10 gp or 10% of the base cost of the item (whichever is higher), or by spending 4 hours and succeeding on a DC 20 repair check with an apporpriate set of tools.

Equipment that is {@b broken} can be repaired for a cost equal to 50% of the base cost of the equipment. The task of repairing broken equipment can only be undertaken in a workshop environment, and takes anywhere from a full day to more than a week depending on the type and quality of the equipment and the extent of the work required. Proofed armor that is broken can only be repaired by a master artisan.

variantrule.name: Wear and Repair; Damaging Equipment
entries: If your group enjoys more tactical combat, consider allowing worn or sundered armor to become damaged on sustaining damage form a critical hit, and a worn or sundered weapon to become damaged when you roll a 1 on the {@dice d20} for an attack roll made with it.

variantrule.name: Wear and Repair; Equipment Properties
entries: The following tags can't be added as upgrades, but may be found preexisting on looted or for-sale items, ar applied automatically when certain conditions are met.

entries.name: Worn or Sundered
entries: This piece of equipment has been damaged in combat or has deteriorated with age and use. A worn or sundered weapons confers a -1 penalty to attack and damage rolls made with it, and the AC of worn or sundered armor is reduced by 1.

entries.name: Damaged
entries: This piece of equipment has sustained significant damage and will break when you roll a 1 on the {@dice d20} for an attack made with it (weapons) or you take damage from a critical hit while wearing it (armor and shields).

entries.name: Broken
entries: A broken weapon or shield cannot be wielded, and the AC of broken armor is reduced by 5, to a minimum of 10.

variantrule.name: Upgrading Armor
entries: There are a number of options available to a character to upgrade their armor, from high-cost armor proofing, to useful additions like insulation suitable for cold weather environments. A complete list of these options, as well as cost and any additional requirements, are shown in the {@table Armor Upgrades|TCAH|Armor Upgrades table} on the following page. In addition to the basic rules for upgrading, the following rules apply when upgrading a suit of armor or a shield with a new tag:

items: Any prerequisite conditions must be satisfied to apply a new tag, as shown in the Armor Upgrades table.
Typically, it takes an artisan a full day of work (minimum 8 hours) to upgrade a suit of armor or a shield with a new tag.

items.name: Armor Proofing
entries: The proofing process normally requires a full workweek (5 days) and can only be undertaken by a master artisan. Once added, armor proofing tags can't be removed from a suit of armor.

entries.name: Armor Proofing
entries: The primary method of upgrading armor, proofing is the process of testing and improving a suit of armor's ability to withstand blows of various types below a certain threshold, being certified as proof against swords, arrows, and warhammers. While all types of armor can be proofed against slashing damage, only medium and heavy armors can be proofed against piercing damage, and only heavy armor can be proofed against bludgeoning attacks.

entries.name: Other Upgrades
entries: In addition to proofing, various other upgrades are available to armors meeting the prerequisites for each, as shown in the Armor Upgrades table. Certain upgrades are incompatible, such as the {@b {@i breathable}} and {@b {@i insulated}} tags, while others have specific requirements (for example, the {@b {@i runic}} tag can only be applied by a runesmith.) Certain types of armor upgrade tags may be removable or temporary. For example, you may be able to remove the {@b {@i muffled}} tag by extracting the padding sewn into the joints. When in doubt, consult with your DM.

entries.name: Variant: Armor Proofing
entries: Your DM might allow you to replace the properties of armor proofing with a bonus to Armor Class. In this case, each tier of proofing provides a cumulative +1 bonus to AC, and the cost of each is tripled.

entries.caption: Armor Upgrades
rows: While wearing this armor, if you would take 6 or less nonmagical slashing damage before resistance is applied, you take none of that damage instead.
Medium or heavy armor with {@i 1st tier armor proofing} tag
While wearing this armor, if you would take 7 or less nonmagical slashing or piercing damage before resistance is applied, you take none of that damage instead.
Heavy armor with the {@i 2nd tier armor proofing} tag
While wearing this armor, if you would take 8 or less nonmagical slashing, piercing, or bludgeoning damage before resistance is applied, you take none of that damage instead.
Light or medium armor. Incompatible with the {@i insulated} tag.
While wearing this armor, you have advantage on saving throws you make against exhaustion effects due to extreme heat, as described in {@book chapter 5|DMG|5} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

This armor has been polished to a mirror finish. While wearing it, you may have advantage on Charisma-based skill checks when interacting with certain humanoids, as determined by the DM. This tag is automatically removed after 24 hours of wear or at the end of a combat.

This armor has been modified with a climbing harness around the midriff, comprising leather straps and quickdraws. While wearing it, you make Strength (Athletics) checks to scale vertical surfaces with advantage when using a rope or similar aid.
Medium or heavy armor and shields
This armor or shield is adorned with a holy symbol and can be used as a spellcasting focus for cleric and paladin spells.
This armor counts as cold weather gear in conditions of extreme cold, as described in {@book chapter 5|DMG|5} of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

This armor is made with hinged joints that can be locked by a quick motion from the wearer. While wearing it, you make Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks to oppose attempts to shove you with advantage.
This armor no longer confers disadvantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.
You can doff this armor as an action.
This armor has been reinforced at the joints and other weak points. While wearing it, critical damage you take from nonmagical attacks is reduced by 3.
{@i Armor proofing} tag (any tier) or a shield. Can only be applied by a runesmith*.
This armor or shield can be imbued with rune magic.*
This armor has been modified with spikes, barbs, or other similar feature, and deals {@dice 1d4} piercing damage to creatures attacking with unarmed strikes or natural weapons that aren't magical.
footnotes: See {@book chapter 2|TCAH|2}, "Rune Magic".

variantrule.name: Variant: Armor Proofing
entries: Your DM might allow you to replace the properties of armor proofing with a bonus to Armor Class. In this case, each tier of proofing provides a cumulative +1 bonus to AC, and the cost of each is tripled.

variantrule.name: Special Ammunition
entries: The following new types of ammunition may be available for ranged weapons; either found as loot, available to purchase, or as an option to craft during downtime:

entries.name: Berserk Dart
entries: The poison in this dart can induce temporary psychosis in a creature subjected to it. When you hit a creature with an attack using this ammunition, it must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or go berserk. While berserk, it must use its action each round to attack the creature nearest to it. At the end of each of its turns, the target can make another Constitution saving throw, ending the effect on a success. A creature that has succeeded on the save has advantage on subsequent saves made to resist the effects of this poison for 24 hours. No effect against undead and creatures immune to being {@condition charmed}. Once a berserk dart hits a creature, it loses this property and becomes a normal dart.

entries.name: Blunt
entries: A flat-nosed arrowhead typically used for target practice and hunting small game animals such as rabbits, squirrels, and grouse. Successful attacks using this ammunition deal {@dice 1d4} nonlethal bludgeoning damage instead of the weapon's normal damage.

entries.name: Bodkin
entries: The tip of a bodkin arrow is most commonly a sharpened spike with a square profile, designed to penetrate plate and mail armor. You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls against targets wearing armor when using this ammunition.

entries.name: Broadhead
entries: With a tip shaped like a spear point, broadheads are designed for maximum penetration of soft flesh and thick hide—commonly used by hunters for bringing down large game. When you hit a creature that isn't wearing armor with an attack using this ammunition it takes an extra {@dice 1d6} piercing damage.

entries.name: Firecracker
entries: This ammunition is tipped with a volatile alchemical compound. On striking a hard surface, it explodes creating a flash of light and loud crack audible out to 100 feet.

entries.name: Shadow
entries: Enchanted with magic from the Shadowfell, this ammunition is able to strike creatures in the Ethereal Plane, and counts as magical for the purposes of overcoming resistance to immunity and nonmagical attacks and damage.

entries.name: Sleep Dart
entries: This dart contains a dose of a powerful soporific, designed to temporarily incapacitate a target. When you hit a creature with an attack using this ammunition, instead of dealing damage roll {@dice 5d8}; if the target has fewer hit points than the total rolled it falls {@condition unconscious} until one hour has passed, it takes damage, or someone uses and action to shake or slap the target awake. No effect against undead and creatures immune to being {@condition charmed}. Once a sleep dart hits a creature, it loses this property and becomes a normal dart.

entries.caption: Special Ammunition
footnotes: The cost of silvered arrows as presented in the Player's Handbook has been reduced by 75%

entries.name: Crafting Special Ammunition
entries: In addition to the appropriate tools for the item to be crafted, a character needs raw materials worth half of the produced item's selling cost. A character proficient with the tools needed to craft the item and with access to the appropriate equipment can craft 10 gp's worth of special ammunition for every 8 hours spent.

magicvariant.name: Silvered Ammunition
entries: Some monsters that have immunity or resistance to nonmagical weapons are susceptible to silver ammunition, so cautious adventurers invest extra coin to plate their ammunition in silver. You can silver ten pieces of ammunition for 25 gp. This cost represents not only the price of the silver, but the time and expertise needed to add silver to the ammunition without making it less effective.

You can silver ten pieces of ammunition for 25 gp. This cost represents not only the price of the silver, but the time and expertise needed to add silver to the ammunition without making it less effective.

This ammunition is tipped with a volatile alchemical compound. On striking a hard surface, it explodes creating a flash of light and loud crack audible out to 100 feet.

magicvariant.name: Bodkin Ammunition
entries: The tip of a bodkin arrow is most commonly a sharpened spike with a square profile, designed to penetrate plate and mail armor. You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls against targets wearing armor when using this ammunition.

The tip of a bodkin arrow is most commonly a sharpened spike with a square profile, designed to penetrate plate and mail armor. You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls against targets wearing armor when using this ammunition.

magicvariant.name: Blunt Ammunition
entries: A flat-nosed arrowhead typically used for target practice and hunting small game animals such as rabbits, squirrels, and grouse. Successful attacks using this ammunition deal {@dice 1d4} nonlethal bludgeoning damage instead of the weapon's normal damage.

A flat-nosed arrowhead typically used for target practice and hunting small game animals such as rabbits, squirrels, and grouse. Successful attacks using this ammunition deal {@dice 1d4} nonlethal bludgeoning damage instead of the weapon's normal damage.

magicvariant.name: Broadhead Ammunition
entries: With a tip shaped like a spear point, broadheads are designed for maximum penetration of soft flesh and thick hide—commonly used by hunters for bringing down large game. When you hit a creature that isn't wearing armor with an attack using this ammunition it takes an extra {@dice 1d6} piercing damage.

With a tip shaped like a spear point, broadheads are designed for maximum penetration of soft flesh and thick hide—commonly used by hunters for bringing down large game. When you hit a creature that isn't wearing armor with an attack using this ammunition it takes an extra {@dice 1d6} piercing damage.

item.name: Berserk Dart (5)
entries: The poison in this dart can induce temporary psychosis in a creature subjected to it. When you hit a creature with an attack using this ammunition, it must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or go berserk. While berserk, it must use its action each round to attack the creature nearest to it. At the end of each of its turns, the target can make another Constitution saving throw, ending the effect on a success. A creature that has succeeded on the save has advantage on subsequent saves made to resist the effects of this poison for 24 hours. No effect against undead and creatures immune to being {@condition charmed}. Once a berserk dart hits a creature, it loses this property and becomes a normal dart.

item.name: Sleep Dart (5)
entries: This dart contains a dose of a powerful soporific, designed to temporarily incapacitate a target. When you hit a creature with an attack using this ammunition, instead of dealing damage roll {@dice 5d8}; if the target has fewer hit points than the total rolled it falls {@condition unconscious} until one hour has passed, it takes damage, or someone uses and action to shake or slap the target awake. No effect against undead and creatures immune to being {@condition charmed}. Once a sleep dart hits a creature, it loses this property and becomes a normal dart.

item.name: Berserk Dart
entries: The poison in this dart can induce temporary psychosis in a creature subjected to it. When you hit a creature with an attack using this ammunition, it must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or go berserk. While berserk, it must use its action each round to attack the creature nearest to it. At the end of each of its turns, the target can make another Constitution saving throw, ending the effect on a success. A creature that has succeeded on the save has advantage on subsequent saves made to resist the effects of this poison for 24 hours. No effect against undead and creatures immune to being {@condition charmed}. Once a berserk dart hits a creature, it loses this property and becomes a normal dart.

item.name: Sleep Dart
entries: This dart contains a dose of a powerful soporific, designed to temporarily incapacitate a target. When you hit a creature with an attack using this ammunition, instead of dealing damage roll {@dice 5d8}; if the target has fewer hit points than the total rolled it falls {@condition unconscious} until one hour has passed, it takes damage, or someone uses and action to shake or slap the target awake. No effect against undead and creatures immune to being {@condition charmed}. Once a sleep dart hits a creature, it loses this property and becomes a normal dart.

item.name: Runesmith's Tools
additionalEntries: Proficiency with runesmith's tools allows you to etch magical runes into precious stones, as well as identify aspects of their lore when encountered in the world. A set of runesmith's tools costs 25 gp and weighs 5 lb.

additionalEntries.name: Components
entries: Runesmith's tools include a hammer, a set of chisels and needle files, a fine-haired brush, a bouch of powdered mithral, and a special alchemical lacquer.

additionalEntries.name: Arcana and History
entries: Your expertise lends you additional insights about lore associated with rounes and other sigils carved into stone or other surface.

additionalEntries.name: Investigation
entries: You can spot clues and make deductions that others might overlook when inspecting items or surfaces carved with runes and other sigils.

additionalEntries.caption: Runesmith's Tools
rows: Identify the properties of a runestone
Determine the creator of a runestone

additionalEntries.name: Moonlighting
entries: Trading in runestones outside of authorized channels is strictly forbidden. Every runesmith leaves an aura—like a magical fingerprint—on runestones they create, so be careful!

item.name: Gambeson
entries: A gambeson is a padded defensive jacket, either worn separately or as an underlay for heavier types of armor. It can also double as a winter coat.

item.name: Lamellar
entries: This is a type of body armor made from small rectangular plates (scales or lamellae) of iron, leather, or bronze laced into horizontal rows.

item.name: Hauberk
entries: A hauberk is a shirt of mail that reaches at least to mid-thigh and includes sleeves.

item.name: Brigandine
entries: Brigandine is a sturdy coat of layered linen or leather lined with small steel plates riveted to the fabric.

item.name: Cuirass
entries: A type of armor formed of a single or multiple pieces of metal that covers the torso. A cuirass generally refers to both a chest plate and back piece together.

item.name: Heater Shield
entries: If the wearer has a Strength score lower than 13, their speed is reduced by 10 feet.

item.name: Tower Shield
entries: If the wearer has a Strength score lower than 15, their speed is reduced by 10 feet.

entries.name: Bandolier
entries: When making a ranged attack with a weapon that has the bandolier property, you can immediately draw another weapon of the same type as part of the attack.

entries.name: Concealed
entries: You have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) checks you make to keep this weapon hidden.

entries.name: Limited
entries: Possession of this weapon is restricted in some soceities, often requiring a special dispensation, rank, or permit.

entries.name: Siege
entries: This weapon deals double damage to objects and structures.

entries.name: Special
entries: You can't make opportunity attacks while holding this shield.

entries.name: Armor proofing: 1st tier
entries: While wearing this armor, if you would take 6 or less nonmagical slashing damage before resistance is applied, you take none of that damage instead.

entries.name: Armor proofing: 2nd tier
entries: While wearing this armor, if you would take 7 or less nonmagical slashing or piercing damage before resistance is applied, you take none of that damage instead.

entries.name: Armor proofing: 3rd tier
entries: While wearing this armor, if you would take 8 or less nonmagical slashing, piercing, or bludgeoning damage before resistance is applied, you take none of that damage instead.

entries.name: Breathable
entries: While wearing this armor, you have advantage on saving throws you make against exhaustion effects due to extreme heat, as described in {@book chapter 5|DMG|5} of the Dungeon Master's Guide.

entries.name: Burnished
entries: This armor has been polished to a mirror finish. While wearing it, you may have advantage on Charisma-based skill checks when interacting with certain humanoids, as determined by the DM. This tag is automatically removed after 24 hours of wear or at the end of a combat.

entries.name: Climbing harness
entries: This armor has been modified with a climbing harness around the midriff, comprising leather straps and quickdraws. While wearing it, you make Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks to scale vertical surfaces with advantage when using a rope or similar aid.

entries.name: Decorated
entries: This armor or shield is adorned with a holy symbol and can be used as a spellcasting focus for cleric and paladin spells.

entries.name: Insulated
entries: This armor counts as cold weather gear in conditions of extreme cold, as described in {@book chapter 5|DMG|5} of the Dungeon Master's Guide.

entries.name: Locking Joints
entries: This armor is made with hinged joints that can be locked by a quick motion from the wearer. While wearing it, you make Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks to oppose attempts to shove you with advantage.

entries.name: Muffled
entries: This armor no longer confers disadvantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.

entries.name: Quick-release clasps
entries: You can doff this armor as an action.

entries.name: Reinforced
entries: This armor has been reinforced at the joints and other weak poitns. While wearing it, critical damage you take from nonmagical attacks is reduced by 3.

entries.name: Runic
entries: This armor or shield can be imbued with {@variantrule rune magic|TCAH}

entries.name: Spiked
entries: This armor has been modified with spikes, barbs, or other similar feature, and deals {@dice 1d4} piercing damage to creatures attacking with unarmed strikes or natural weapons that aren't magical.

table.caption: Runesmithing Success Rate—Double Proficiency
footnotes: * Assumes Dexterity or Intelligence as a primary ability score with a typical rate of progression using the Standard Array.

rows: Modest lifestyle for the week + 5 gp per day of work
Comfortable lifestyle for the week + 10 gp per day of work
Wealthy lifestyle for the week + 20 gp per day of work
Aristocratic lifestyle for the week + 50 gp per day of work.

table.name: Guild Work Complications
rows: A customer cancels an order, reducing your earnings for the week by one category.
You work for a lucrative contract, increasing your earnings for the week b one rank category.
Your tools are damaged or stolen, forcing you to buy new ones.*
An incident occurs in the workhall for which you are blamed (justified or not, as you choose). You are barred from the workhall for the next 6 workweeks.*
You are accused of selling runestones outide of guild channels by a colleague.*
A runestone bearing your magical signature was used to commit a crime.*
footnotes: * Might involve a rival.

footnotes: The cost of silvered arrows as presented in the Player's Handbook has been reduced by 75%

You gain a +1 bonus to damage rolls made with this weapon.

When you attack with this weapon and roll the maximum result for the weapon's damage dice, you can roll these dice again and add the new roll to the damage of the attack. If you roll the maximum amount again, you can repeat this process until you don't.
